terms.definition: Temporary running stitch with long, easily removable stitches used to hold fabric in place during fittings or before permanent stitching. Essential for alterations and bespoke tailoring.
The seam where the collar of a jacket meets the lapel. The height and angle of the gorge significantly affects the jacket's style and formality.
The armhole opening of a jacket or shirt where the sleeve attaches. Proper armscye measurement and construction is crucial for comfort and range of motion.
How much the trouser leg drapes onto the shoe. Options include no break (modern, shorter), slight break (contemporary), medium break (traditional), or full break (one full fold at shoe).
The tailoring technique of tapering or taking in the waist of a jacket to create a more pronounced V-shape silhouette and emphasize the torso.
Hand-sewing technique using small diagonal stitches to attach canvas to fabric, creating the break and shape in lapels and collars. Hallmark of quality tailoring.

Layer of stiff fabric (traditionally horsehair and wool) placed between outer fabric and lining of a jacket to provide structure and shape. Full canvas extends throughout chest; half canvas only in chest area; fused uses glued interlining instead.
Diagonal direction of fabric at 45-degree angle to selvedge. Fabric cut on bias has maximum stretch and drape, used for binding edges and creating flowing garments.
The finished edge of woven cloth that runs parallel to warp threads. Doesn't fray and indicates straight grain of fabric.
Direction of threads in woven cloth. Lengthwise grain runs parallel to selvedge (warp threads), crosswise grain runs perpendicular to selvedge (weft threads), and bias is diagonal.
Raised surface on fabric created by fiber ends, giving directional texture. Velvet, corduroy, and some wools have nap. All pattern pieces must be cut in same direction for consistent appearance.
Small V-shaped cut in seam allowance used to mark pattern placement or clip curves. Also refers to notch lapel style where collar and lapel meet at angle.
Lapel style where the lapel points upward toward the shoulder. More formal than notch lapel, often found on double-breasted jackets and tuxedos.
Rounded collar and lapel cut as one continuous piece without gorge seam. Most formal lapel style, typically seen on tuxedos and smoking jackets.
Opening or slit in a garment, usually with finished edges. Common on shirt fronts (button placket), cuffs, and necklines.
Fitted part of a garment at shoulders or hips from which the rest of the garment hangs. Shirt yokes provide shoulder shaping and decorative detail.
Triangular or diamond-shaped piece of fabric inserted to add strength or allow movement in stress areas such as underarms or crotch.
Layer of fabric placed between outer fabric and lining to add structure, support, and shape. Can be sew-in or fusible (iron-on). Essential in collars, cuffs, and waistbands.
Layer of fabric cut identically to garment pieces and treated as one with fashion fabric during construction. Adds body and structure throughout garment.
Trimming seam allowances to different widths to reduce bulk, especially important in curved seams and heavy fabrics. Creates smoother, flatter seams.

Extra fullness worked into a seam to create shape without gathers or darts. Essential for setting sleeves and creating curved seams. Also refers to wearing ease - extra room beyond body measurements for comfort and movement.
Custom-made clothing created from scratch for individual client with multiple fittings. True bespoke includes hand-cut pattern and significant handwork. Highest level of custom tailoring.
Clothing created from existing pattern adjusted to individual measurements. Less expensive than bespoke with fewer fittings, but still customized to client.
Decorative hand-sewing technique creating small, evenly-spaced stitches along edges of lapels and pockets. Sign of quality tailoring and hand finishing.
Triangular fold of fabric stitched to create shape and contour. Darts remove excess fabric and help garment conform to body curves.
Fabric fold that adds fullness or creates design detail. Can be pressed (knife pleat, box pleat) or unpressed (soft pleat). Common in trousers and skirts.
Area between seam line and raw edge of fabric. Standard allowances vary by garment type and sewing method, typically 1/2 to 5/8 inch.
Visible stitching on the right side of garment, usually parallel to seam or edge. Can be decorative or functional, adds strength and design element.
Stitching through facing and seam allowances close to seamline, preventing facing from rolling to outside of garment. Invisible from right side.
Single line of stitching within seam allowance on curved or bias edges to prevent stretching during construction. Done immediately after cutting.
Enclosed seam where raw edges are completely enclosed. Creates clean finish on both sides. Ideal for sheer fabrics and reversible garments.
Strong, flat seam where one seam allowance encloses the other. Visible topstitching. Common in jeans and workwear.
Heavy-duty thread used for sewing buttonholes, decorative topstitching, and attaching buttons. Stronger and thicker than regular sewing thread.
Tailored buttonhole with fabric-bound opening rather than stitched edges. Sign of high-quality tailoring. More time-consuming than machine buttonholes.
Tailored pocket with fabric-bound opening, creating clean line. Common on suit jackets and dress trousers. Can be single or double welt.
Pocket with fabric flap covering opening. Most common on suit jackets. Flap can be tucked inside pocket for cleaner line.
Pocket sewn onto garment exterior. Most casual pocket style. Common on blazers, sport coats, and casual shirts.
Small pocket above regular pocket on right side of jacket. Originally for train tickets. Now decorative detail associated with British tailoring.
Pocket with narrow welt opening, cleaner than flap pocket. Common on formal wear and tuxedos. American term for welt pocket.
Pocket on left chest of jacket for pocket square. Should be functional, not just decorative welt. Depth and angle affect pocket square display.
Slits at bottom back of jacket allowing movement and comfort when sitting. Options: no vent (formal, American), center vent (common, American), side vents (British, most flattering).
Functional buttonholes on jacket sleeves, as opposed to decorative sewn-shut buttons. Sign of quality tailoring, allows cuff adjustments.
Jacket sleeves with working buttonholes that actually unbutton, allowing sleeves to be rolled up. Originally for surgeons, now luxury detail.
Sleeve buttons placed so close together they touch or nearly touch. Detail associated with Italian tailoring.
Sleeve head with pronounced roll or rope-like appearance at shoulder seam. British tailoring feature, creates dramatic silhouette.
Minimal padding and soft shoulder construction following body's natural line. American Ivy League style, opposite of structured European shoulder.
Sharply tailored shoulder with defined, extended shoulder line. Associated with 1980s power suits and Italian tailoring.
Partial lining covering only upper back of jacket. Provides structure where needed while keeping jacket lighter and cooler. Common in summer jackets.
Lining covering upper back and extending to mid-back. Cooler than full lining while providing structure. Popular in casual and summer jackets.
Canvas layer attached loosely to jacket fabric with pad stitching rather than fused. Allows fabric to move naturally, creating better drape and longevity.
Hand-sewn buttonhole with keyhole shape at one end, allowing button shank to sit comfortably. Sign of true bespoke tailoring.
Machine stitching that mimics hand pick stitching. Named after American Machine & Foundry company. Used on ready-to-wear to simulate bespoke appearance.
Line where lapel naturally folds away from jacket body. Created through pad stitching and pressing. Determines lapel character and appearance.
Italian for 'shirt sleeve'. Jacket sleeve construction method where sleeve is attached like shirt sleeve, creating soft, natural shoulder.
